data: PAL Palliative Care Epidural Analgesia (Module)
Admit/Transfer/Discharge
Physician to review all previous opioid and CNS depressant orders
Initial epidural insertion by anaesthesiologist
Ongoing epidural, analgesic and adjuvant management by Palliative Care physician
Patient Care
Notify Treating Provider
If inadequate analgesia or any problems identified related to Epidural Catheter System
Notify Treating Provider Vital Signs
T;N, RR < 6, Numbness above the nipples and or inability to bend knees
Peripheral IV Care
Maintain IV access for 24 hours after epidural infusion stopped
Respiratory Rate
If Respiratory Rate is 8/min or less:
Sedation Assessment
If Sedation Score (POSS) 3 or greater:

When pain is well controlled at stable infusion rate and discharge planning begins, assessments may be reduced to daily or as needed. After discontinuation of the epidural, be aware that epidural narcotic effect may last for 9 hours for fentanyl and 24 hours for morphine
Upon initiation of epidural infusion:
Vital Signs
q1h for 4 hour, then q4h for 8 hour, thereafter q12h
Pulse Oximetry
q1h for 4 hour, then q4h for 8 hour, thereafter q12h
Sedation Assessment
q1h for 4 hour, then q4h for 8 hour, thereafter q12h
Pain Assessment
q1h for 4 hour, then q4h for 8 hour, thereafter q12h
Motorsensory Assessment
q4h for 12 hours, thereafter q12h while awake and when clinically indicated using ice
Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity Assessment (LAST)
Assess for systemic side effects of local anesthetic q4h while awake
Bladder Scan
q8h, Check bladder distension
In and Out Catheterization
PRN, Check bladder distention q8h
Nursing Reminder
If Respiratory Compromise secondary to bupivacaine - Obtain assistance with Manual Ventilation by calling RT/Code Blue
Medications
For custom epidural medication (bupivacaine 0.1%-fentanyl 4 mcg/mL, bupivacaine 0.1%-morphone 50 mcg/mL and HYDROmorphone 10 mcg/m), Pharmacy requires 2 hours notice to prepare

Some solutions are Pharmacy Custom solutions and may not be available at all sites or after-hours (after 23:00).  Please follow local site protocols and ensure adequate time for custom solution preparation

Respiratory
Oxygen Therapy
Titrate O2 to keep SpO2 92% or greater, Nasal Cannula, for 48 hour, 2-4 L/min via nasal prongs except when patient is ambulating
Titrate O2 to keep SpO2 88 - 92 %, Nasal Cannula, for 48 hour, for known/suspected CO2 retainers; 2-4 L/min via nasal prongs except when patient is ambulating
Oxygen Therapy
10 L/min if naloxone administered
Consults/Referrals
Consider consultation with  Anesthesia and Addiction Services
